comments.body:
@bashtage If one wanted to write this code a bit more expanded would the below variable names be good:

```
from numpy.random import MT19937

random_generator_container = MT19937(12345)
random_generator = random_generator_container.generator

print(random_generator.standard_normal())
```

I'm asking for my own understanding, but do you think it could be useful to the reader to have the container concept explained?

It could be useful to add here something like:

'The above code is equivalent to:
from numpy.random import Xoroshiro128
rg = Xoroshiro128().generator
rg.standard_normal()'

It creates an additional step to understanding the concept of a default brng and using another brng as shown next when passing a seed to the MT brng.
[TODO]: For me. I agree that this would also be nneficial.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +52,56 @@  rg.standard_normal()
  rg.bit_generator


Seeds can be passed to any of the BitGenerators. Here `mt19937.MT19937` is used

@@ -1,1 +88,92 @@
  from numpy.random import default_gen
  rg = default_gen(12345)
  rg.random()

comments.body: see comment elsewhere about bad refs from #14608

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +33,37 @@-----------

By default, `~Generator` uses bits provided by `PCG64` which
has better statistical properties than the legacy mt19937 random
number generator in `~.RandomState`.

comments.body: Sphinx does not need the `.RandomState` nor the `~.RandomState` formatting to create the link to `RandomState`.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +23,27 @@distributions. See `NEP 19 <https://www.numpy.org/neps/
nep-0019-rng-policy.html>`_ for context on the updated random Numpy number
routines. The legacy `RandomState` random number routines are still
available, but limited to a single BitGenerator.

comments.body: Rework the documentation in lines 36-52 to better guide users how to modify existing code to call `default_rng`

Call `default_rng` to get a new instance of a `Generator`, then call its

comments.body: Aren't there more bit generators in `randomgen`? If so, that seems worth mentioning. Otherwise, this subsection is probably best moved to `THANKS.txt`, it doesn't help the user.
There are many more there still.
